addressleaf.section:
De Mons
r
Bodley le 2
me
de mars a Mons
r
le comte d'Essex
1594
.

page.lettertext:
fol.163r
May it please y
r
good Lp. it was y
r
pleasure
to will me when I
ted from home, to write of any
thinge whatsoever so I writt unto you often: w
ch
order I will followe till y
r
Lp. be weary & bidde me
take an other course.
M
r
Devinston
the
Scottishe Ambassador ligger hath ben with me of
purpose to ease his stomacke of dislike of this coming
hither of
Coronell Stuart:
aswell in respect of his
demaund of assistance, w
ch
if it be money he thinkes
is wholly lost: as of the mariage be sollicited
betweene th'
Earle of Orchney
& the
sister
of
Co.
Maurice
: under cullour whereof he saieth
t
Co.
Stuart doth practise somewhat elce: & yet for
ought I can
ceive he seemeth to be ignorant of
his private instructions. And thus he uttereth his
phansie not onelie to be, but in secret co
m
unication
to diverse of the
States:
howbeit as I am
informed he is a creature of the
chauncellor,
aswell as the Coronell. Both by him & the rest
of the nation, here Stuart is reputed a papiste, &
a spaniard in hart, & of a lousie disposic
o
n: not
as they affirme, beloved of the
K
; nor of many
men in
Scotland.
And thoghe they speake
it, I finde somewhat of the splene, yet many
men concurring in one co
m
on conceite, I
will take it for a caveat to observe his
ceeding
. The 26 of the last
I sent y
r
Lp the copies of certaine l
res
intercepted, in w
ch
was a note of a speciall
sonage,
t
would be wonne as he thought
to doe a singular peece of service, it meanes
might be found to recompence his losses.
fol.163v
I have ben somewhat inquisitive, to know amonge
the scott
who
e
tie might be, by their conjecture
but they are all in a muse, not knowing whom to
ghesse at: though their chiefest suspic
o
n runne
upon the L. Humes; by reason of aliaunce be-
tweene him &
Thomas Tyrie
. The Coronell in his
discourse doth rather ghesse the
L. Atholl,
tlie
for th'affection
t
he beareth to
Bothwell,
&
tlie
for a pique, w
ch
he saith is growen of late between
him &
Argile.
I cannot yet
ceave by any
circumstance heere,
t
Stuart hath imparted
his private instructions to any one of the state.
w
ch
makes mee thinke
t
his charge was to
ceede
in such sorte, as he should finde mens disposic
o
ns
wherein I thinke he is deceaved.
I have had a l
re
from y
r
Lp. by
Captaine Berry
whereof the date was omitted: & the tenor
was onelie to lett me know
t
her
Ma
tie
complai-
ned of my silence: in w
ch
behalfe I trust by this
shee is very well satisfied.
And so I take
my humble leave.
From the Hage Marche 2 1594.
Y
r
Lps most humbly bounden. Tho. Bodley.
